original_data.question:
A 32-year-old man comes to the physician for a pre-employment examination. He recently traveled to Guatemala. He feels well but has not seen a physician in several years, and his immunization records are unavailable. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Anti-HAV IgM Positive
Anti-HAV IgG Negative
HBsAg Negative
Anti-HBs Positive
HBcAg Negative
Anti-HBc Negative
HBeAg Negative
Anti-HBe Negative
Anti-HCV Negative
Which of the following best explains this patient's laboratory findings?"

model_response:
This patient has evidence of past infection with hepatitis B virus (HBsAg negative, anti-HBs positive), but no current infection (HBeAg negative, anti-HBe positive). The presence of anti-HCV indicates that he has not been infected with the hepatitis C virus. The presence of anti-HAV IgM indicates that this patient has had a recent hepatitis A infection.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

Deliberate stimulation of the host's immune response. ACTIVE IMMUNIZATION involves administration of ANTIGENS or IMMUNOLOGIC ADJUVANTS. PASSIVE IMMUNIZATION involves administration of IMMUNE SERA or LYMPHOCYTES or their extracts (e.g., transfer factor, immune RNA) or transplantation of immunocompetent cell producing tissue (thymus or bone marrow).
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
The study of serum, especially of antigen-antibody reactions in vitro.
An antibody produced by B lymphocytes in response to hepatitis A enteroviral infection.
